summary: Thanos Has Too Strong of a Rectum for Ant-Man to Grow Inside and Kill Him, 'Avengers: Endgame' Co-Writer Confirms
title: Thanos Has Too Strong of a Rectum for Ant-Man to Grow Inside and Kill Him, 'Avengers: Endgame' Co-Writer Confirms
excerpt: If you watched Avengers: Endgame waiting for the Ant-Man attacking Thanos butt plan to happen, the film's co-writer explains why it wouldn't have worked.

blog.description: I am a human person with thoughts and feelings Feminist | she/her | anxiety disorder | emotional about lady superheroes.

summary: If Tony really was ready to die for the Dusted, why not have him and Rhodey or him and Steve (to really drive Stony shippers...
body:
If Tony really was ready to die for the Dusted, why not have him and Rhodey or him and Steve (to really drive Stony shippers mad), go to Vormir?

Because the way it is now, Nat dies to save everyone. Tony dies just to kill Thanos.

I don’t know why I ask these questions. I know the answer is that they wanted to keep RDJ there to the last fucking minute and give him all th screentime.

It just frustrates me that the filmmakers act like it was either Clint or Natasha who had to die there, never even entertaining other possibilities. But I still don’t understand why it’s okay to kill any one of our “core six” so early in the film, let alone the only female.

tags: you can tell a woman got done dirty and joined the ranks
most lately nat which... yeah though tbh you could say that since forever
but like. you can tell who was treated by crap/got fridged/got written out/is unfairly hated by fandom by those edits

summary: ‎The Empire Film Podcast: Avengers: Endgame Spoiler Special Interviews ft. The Russos and Markus/McFeely on Apple Podcasts
body:
‎The Empire Film Podcast: Avengers: Endgame Spoiler Special Interviews ft. The Russos and Markus/McFeely on Apple Podcasts

Part two of this series of posts where I listen to the writers and directors of ENDGAME.

They talk about Joe’s cameo how “representation is huge” for them. Blah blah.

Asked how old Cap is in this timeline at the end of the movie and the Russos are like “there’s some missing story there.” Some people would call that a plot HOLE. That is an interesting dodge.

Re: Clint. “He didn’t lose to Thanos.” His experience is different. They talk about him losing his family as one of the “most interesting” to them. Joe talks about having dour kids (two of which are in the movie).

Interviewer suggests each of the Avengers has responds with one of the traditional “Five Stages of Grief.” I think that is giving them too much credit.

They call Thor “tragic” and say he is “beating himself up physically” for his failure. The interviewer asks about playing that for comedy, which I think is a good question. They say they don’t say the movie is funny until Hulk in the diner, then Joe backtracks and says “when Rudd shows up” is when there is hope and that is when there is allowed to be humor.

Interviewer asks why he doesn’t get his body back when Mjolnir comes to him and they say “Thor can’t wash this off that quickly,” that this has “changed him.” Definitely use the word “depressed” for him.

They say Thor is ready to go on a journey of self disovery which is where a lot of the Guardians are.

“Dad bod Thor” can still kick ass they say. I just realized this movie is basically all about fatherhood.

Regarding Steve, they say Tony and Steve’s are intertwined and since Tony was meant to die… then they trail off. I think they maybe forced Steve into what they think is a “happy” ending because Tony couldn’t have that? That talk about what he “deserved” and I guess my question is why is getting married and having kids the only happy ending that was on the table?

[i take a break]

summary: I personaggi morti in Avengers: Endgame torneranno mai in vita?
title: I personaggi morti in Avengers: Endgame torneranno mai in vita?
body:
I personaggi morti in Avengers: Endgame torneranno mai in vita?

La domanda nella testa della maggior parte dei fan Marvel non può che essere questa: Torneranno mai in vita i personaggi morti in Avengers: Endgame?

Ovviamente al momento non è dato sapere se Iron Man o Vedova Nera torneranno in vita nel futuro del Marvel Cinematic Universe, ma a dare una sorta di risposta ai fan ci ha provato uno dei due sceneggiatori del film, Christopher Markus.

Durante…

summary: So I finally watched Avengers: Endgame and here are my thoughts:
title: So I finally watched Avengers: Endgame and here are my thoughts:
body:
I think that if you’ve seen all the MCU movies, you look at this one differently than someone who only watched some of them. I know because I went to cinema with my boyfriend who was this kind of casual viewer. It’s not just the fact that some little details can be lost, if one didn’t see, say, Captain America: Winter Soldier. It’s that when the final battle happens and the “snapped” characters come back, along with their respectful supporting cast, it feels… earned. It feels like this is what all those ten years were building up for - every superhero, from every corner of the established universe (minus TV shows; which is a shame).

Then we have Tony Stark’s funeral and the camera is moving slowly from main Avengers, through Spiderman, Guardians of the Galaxy, Scarlet Witch etc, and the finishes on the kid from Iron Man 3 and Nick Fury. It’s like a beautiful send-off to a character that started the franchise.

And then there are the closing credits which list all the heroes that made this beautiful extended universe and there is a sense of closure.

Now, you know me - I’m not very fond of Tony Stark. And I agree that his rant where he basically calls Cap a liar is bullshit. However, I’ve got a sense that right after he figures out how to make time travel non-lethal he tried to subtly make up for certain things. For example, I’ve seen him giving Steve back his shield as a form of peace offering. Like he was trying to say: “I want to help you know. Let’s save the world together.”

Then there is the segment in 1970 which is very special to me, because once upon a time I’ve written two fics in which - thanks to time travel - Tony Stark and other Avengers get to meet younger Howard Stark and Tony manages to talk with him. In the second fic there is a plot point where Steve assumes the alias of captain Roger Stevens, so yeah… pretty cool.

I don’t hate Steve’s ending. I don’t think that he abandoned his friends. I think that he deserves to get his life back; to finally go on a retirement, especially because this scene happens when the fight is over and both Sam and Bucky expressed nothing but gladness because of Steve’s happiness.

I also liked the scenes that were about Doctor Strange. Like the fact that Ancient One decides to trust Strange’s plan and how she talks about him; or the scene when he and the other mages were the ones bringing the cavalry through the portals.

Also, my personal highlight of this movie: Steve Rogers referencing the infamous “Hail Hydra” panel to get the Tesseract.

I’m glad I’ve seen this movie. It seemed like a Crowning Moment for Avangers movies and now a new era will start in the MCU.

summary: Avengers: Endgame Almost Had Iron Man Time Travel Back to a Different MCU Movie
title: Avengers: Endgame Almost Had Iron Man Time Travel Back to a Different MCU Movie
body:
Avengers: Endgame Almost Had Iron Man Time Travel Back to a Different MCU Movie

Avengers: Endgame co-screenwriter Stephen McFeely uncovers the film about returned to another Marvel Cinematic Universe motion picture. Eventually, the choice was changed to return so as to the main Avengers motion picture, which is likely generally advantageous. MCU fans were eager to see Tony Stark, Bruce Banner, and Steve Rogers return to the Battle of New York, despite the fact that Smart…

tags: what we do in the shadows
title: Weekly Roundup: June 3-7, 2019
body:
Weekly Roundup: June 3-7, 2019

Greetings, readers! Welcome to another week and (now another month!) at Speculative Chic. I hope things in your corner of the world are sunny, warm, and comfortable as the summer begins. In my neck of the woods, we have an extra season crammed inside summer called “tsuyu,” or, the rainy season, which has started early this year. Thank goodness I have a dehumidifer at home and plenty of geeky…

Weekly Roundup: June 3-7, 2019

External image

Greetings, readers! Welcome to another week and (now another month!) at Speculative Chic. I hope things in your corner of the world are sunny, warm, and comfortable as the summer begins. In my neck of the woods, we have an extra season crammed inside summer called “tsuyu,” or, the rainy season, which has started early this year. Thank goodness I have a dehumidifer at home and plenty of geeky…

View On WordPress

blog.name: voicemailsfrompeterparker
blog.title: Voicemails From Peter Parker
blog.description:
A collection of voicemail transcriptions from Peter Parker to Tony Stark.
Documented by F.R.I.D.A.Y and @foxbowl (updates every Friday). 

Click here to see Peter's voicemails in chronological order!
Request for a voicemail and F.R.I.D.A.Y. will try to find it in her archives ↓

tags: *in captain america's voice* so... you thought this was a comedy account
summary: ————————————————————— Voicemail #49 To: Peter Parker From: Tony Stark I deleted ‘Project Parker’ today. All of it, every file...
body:
—————————————————————

Voicemail #49

To: Peter Parker

From: Tony Stark

I deleted ‘Project Parker’ today. All of it, every file related to the Decimation, every folder with information on how we could get you back. I had F.R.I.D.A.Y. burn it, burn it all.

I changed the name from ‘Project Parker’ to just ‘Project’ before I did it. I don’t think I could delete it all with your name still attached. But getting rid of a few words doesn’t make me feel any better. It makes me feel like a monster. Because I know I let you- and the rest of the universe- down.

Selfish is what I’ve been called more times than I can remember. But it hit me different when I finally realized it was every bit true. While the world mourns, I’ve moved to a cabin away from reality. While the rest of civilization is in chaos, I’ve started a new life- the best life than I’ve ever had. And now, when I finally realized that maybe, just maybe, the answer to reversing what happened might be time-travel, I give up.

Time-travel, which would also reverse everything I’ve had these last four years, which would take away Morgan- my daughter I would die for any day. Time-travel, which would bring you back, but in the back of my head, it’s become just a blur of a thought. There’s so many things that could go wrong. Catastrophically. It could make things worse than they are now. Four years ago, I would have gone for it anyways, ignoring any consequences and taking a leap of faith. But now, I’ve realized I don’t want to dwell on the past- I want to move on. And it hurts like hell to think that. But, at the same time, I feel relieved.

I’m sorry, Peter. You were better than I ever was. And it kills me to let you go.

But I am.

—————————————————————

—————————————————————

summary: Not to sound like a Steve defender or anything, but why is everyone pretending that he and Peggy barely knew each other?? All...
body: Not to sound like a Steve defender or anything, but why is everyone pretending that he and Peggy barely knew each other?? All I’m seeing is people saying “they only knew each other for like 2 minutes” (I’m aware this is not literal) but they knew each other for a few months, at the very least. TFA seems to take place over a pretty large expanse of time, with all the events we see and the montages and everything. They were close friends when he crashed the plane which is why his supposed death affected her so much. I know we’re all pissed with how Endgame ended, but please can we stop acting like Steve’s some weird stalker who went back in time for someone he barely knew.

summary: You know what means so much to me is Tony Stark being a better father than Howard. There’s definitely a learning curve with...
body:
You know what means so much to me is Tony Stark being a better father than Howard. There’s definitely a learning curve with Peter, and, yes, he messed up. But just look at how he handles being Morgan’s dad (and yes, I know that, as ever, that’s RDJ shining through).

Speaking as someone who also had a shitty dad and who is determined to do a better job for her own kids someday, that just means so, so much to me. 

Your parents’ mistakes do not define you as a parent.

summary: i would understand if someone like made steve go to group therapy and he didn’t want to talk so he decided to talk about...
body:
i would understand if someone like made steve go to group therapy and he didn’t want to talk so he decided to talk about something less painful and recent like losing peggy over talking about sam and bucky

but they really expected me to believe he was more sad about a woman he never even got to go on a date with then two of his best friends (and a few other friends) disappearing, one of which happened right in front of him

what a joke!

tags: who knows if this made any sense
summary: At this point in the movie, Thor was pretty clearly distraught. That was one of the reasons I think that Tony says he’s in no...
body:
I’m just thinking out loud here …

At this point in the movie, Thor was pretty clearly distraught. That was one of the reasons I think that Tony says he’s in no condition. Because (IMO) you have to have a clear head when it comes to making the snap.

But then, thirty-ish minutes later, Stark uses the stones himself. Who says Tony was in the right condition? He had more to live for than some of the others. He had a wife and daughter at home, and he’d just gotten Peter back. Wouldn’t sacrificing himself make Tony pretty distraught as well? Would he have been in the right “condition” to use the stones?

My answer is yes.

Tony is a man who is used to the idea of dying. For years, he was living on borrowed time with that shrapnel in his chest. He’s used to the idea that he might die. While the other heroes are probably used to it and/or maybe even long for it, Tony was I think the only one who had accepted it. Who had a clear head, and knew exactly what needed to be “wished for” when the stones were used.

I’ve wondered about this scene before. Would Thor have maybe tried to bring back his mother, his father, and Loki? Not on purpose, but depending on how the stones work, I wonder if that’s what could have potentially happened if Thor had been the one to snap his fingers. If Thor had been distracted at all and not focusing?

The reason I think Tony was able to destroy Thanos’ army was because he HAD his whole world back, and he knew they could get by without him. It would be hard for them, yes, but Tony knew EXACTLY what had to happen. He wasn’t worried about bringing anyone else back. And that was why Tony was able to snap his fingers and turn Thanos and his army to dust.

Don’t get me wrong. I dislike the fact that Tony died (so much in fact I’m writing a fanfic where he doesn’t die). Also, don’t get me wrong, i absolutely love Thor. I’m just thinking out loud here about why Tony was in the right condition to snap the stones when Thor wasn’t.

summary: season 4 of korra reminds me of endgame. it’s set years after the last installment, the main characters have different lives,...
body: season 4 of korra reminds me of endgame. it’s set years after the last installment, the main characters have different lives, everyone’s older, the main character has ptsd, the heroes are living among normal people, i’m in too much shock to be sad or confused about any of it
